summary.text_en: Ptolemy established complete geocentric system! His 'Almagest' summarized ancient Greek astronomy achievements, using epicycle-deferent model to explain planetary motion. Though geocentrism later overturned, his system dominated Western astronomy for 1400 years, pinnacle of ancient science.

story.text_en: Around 150 AD, Ptolemy worked in Alexandria. He faced puzzle: if Earth is universe center, why does Mars sometimes 'retrograde' (move backward)? He designed clever epicycle-deferent model: planets move on small circle (epicycle), which moves on large circle (deferent). This explained retrograde! He wrote this system into 13-volume 'Almagest', becoming medieval astronomy's bible.

fun_facts.text_en: 'Almagest' is Arabic for 'the greatest', original Greek title was 'Mathematical Compilation'.
His 'Geography' drew world map, marking coordinates of 8000 locations!
He also wrote music theory works, studying mathematical relationships of scales and harmony.
His geocentrism dominated 1400 years until overturned by Copernicus.

experiment.description_en: Ptolemy's epicycle-deferent model could precisely predict planetary retrograde. For example, Mars retrogrades about every 2 years, lasting ~2 months. By adjusting epicycle and deferent sizes and speeds, Ptolemy could calculate Mars position at any moment, error only few degrees. This predictive ability made geocentrism unchallengeable for 1400 years, until Tycho's precise observations found larger errors.
experiment.why_en: Though epicycle-deferent model based on wrong geocentric assumption, mathematically could fit observational data - that's why it lasted so long.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine you standing still at playground center, watching classmates run around you. But one classmate strange, running big circle around you while also running small circles, sometimes appearing to go backward! Ptolemy said: planets move like this. They rotate on small circle (epicycle), small circle rotates on large circle (deferent). Though this idea wrong (actually Earth moving), quite accurate for predicting planet positions!

impact.text_en: 'Almagest' was culmination of ancient science, summarizing astronomy achievements from Hipparchus to his era. His geocentric system dominated Western astronomy 1400 years until Copernicus proposed heliocentrism. Though geocentrism wrong, Ptolemy's mathematical methods and observation techniques laid foundation for later astronomical revolution. His 'Geography' also influenced medieval and Renaissance cartography.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Star catalog, precession discovery and trigonometry

influenced.contribution_en: Arab astronomers preserved and developed Ptolemaic system
Precise observations found errors in Ptolemaic system
Replaced Ptolemy's circular orbits with elliptical orbits

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Ptolemy synthesized Hipparchus's observational data, Aristotle's cosmology, and Apollonius's epicycle theory, establishing complete geocentric system. Arab astronomers preserved and improved his works in Middle Ages. Copernicus studying Ptolemaic system's complexity, proposed simpler heliocentrism. Tycho's precise observations exposed Ptolemaic model flaws. Kepler finally replaced circular orbits with elliptical ones, completely overturning Ptolemaic system.

quiz.question_en: What model did Ptolemy use to explain planetary retrograde?
quiz.explanation_en: Ptolemy invented epicycle-deferent model to explain planetary retrograde. In this model, planets move on small circle (epicycle), epicycle center moves on large circle (deferent) around Earth. When planet moves backward on epicycle, appears retrograde from Earth. Though this model based on wrong geocentric assumption, mathematically could fit observational data well, thus dominated astronomy for 1400 years.
